greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Given n-th prime p, a(n)=number of primes of the form p+q+1 where q is any prime < p.
comment: Conjecture: a(n)>0 for all n>3. - _Dmitry Kamenetsky_, Feb 09 2017
link: Zak Seidov, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: For n=5, p=11, there are a(5)=2 solutions from 11+5+1=17 and 11+7+1=19.
mathematica: Table[p = Prime[n]; c = 0; i = 1; While[i < n, If[PrimeQ[p + Prime[i] + 1], c = c + 1]; i++]; c, {n, 72}]
Table[p = Prime[n] + 1; Sum[If[PrimeQ[p + Prime[i]], 1, 0], {i, 1, n - 1}], {n, 72}] (* _Zak Seidov_, Apr 19 2013 *)
program: (PARI) for(n = 1,72, q = prime (n) + 1; print1 (sum (i = 1, n - 1, isprime (q + prime (i))) ","))\\ _Zak Seidov_, Apr 19 2013
results.author: _Jayanta Basu_, Apr 19 2013
